executive_summary: Diagnostic imaging centers play a crucial role in the US healthcare system, serving as the primary point of contact for patients seeking diagnostic imaging services. Imaging centers receive referrals from various healthcare providers, including hospitals, primary care physicians and specialists. As healthcare expenditure rises, diagnostic imaging centers receive more referrals as patients seek better health outcomes. An aging population's expanding medical needs drive growing medical spending, as aging adults have a higher incidence of disease and injury. The COVID-19 pandemic's disruption to healthcare spending disrupted diagnostic imaging, as healthcare focused on emergency care and coronavirus patients. Yet, recovering patient volumes for elective care offset this, leading revenue to expand at a CAGR of 0.8% to an estimated $23.8 billion over the past five years. As patient volumes remain steady and healthcare expenditure dwindles, growth in 2023 will be more moderate, increasing an estimated 0.3% by year-end.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated chronic staffing shortages and staff burnout at imaging centers. Many centers are turning to artificial intelligence (AI) tools to provide cost savings, create clinical efficiency and reduce the workload of radiologists while offering improved patient outcomes. Still, robust integration of AI remains a challenge. Advances in imaging equipment are also available, but high purchasing costs limit adoption.

The diagnostic imaging landscape will remain fragmented moving forward, but consolidation activity will increase as cost pressures strain profit. Stringent reimbursement cuts by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) will hurt imaging centers as the number of Medicare-eligible patients increases. Concurrently, reimbursements from private providers, where imaging centers have more negotiating power, will be subtle due to subdued growth in private coverage. Cost pressures will incentivize small.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Artificial Intelligence Can Alleviate the Brunt of Staffing Shortages
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: An aging population will translate into a higher consumption of healthcare services. As healthcare utilization expands, imaging centers will receive more referrals from hospitals and specialty physicians. Tech advances will improve diagnostic imaging centers' operations, as new imaging equipment and artificial intelligence will provide better patient outcomes and clinical efficiency. Staffing shortages and higher rates of burnout will incentivize imaging centers to adopt artificial intelligence (AI) tools. AI can produce short- and long-run cost savings while improving patient care.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changes in Third-Party Payer Policies Will Squeeze Profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Subtle growth in private health insurance coverage will stunt private insurers' spending on healthcare services. Imaging centers have more power in contract negotiations with private payers, resulting in higher reimbursement rates. Slow growth in private insurance coverage will limit revenue from private insurance providers. Medicare and other third-party payers are expected to implement more stringent reimbursement cuts moving forward. Reimbursement cuts will disproportionately affect imaging centers participating with Medicare and Medicaid. Imaging centers could feel reimbursement cuts deeply as they receive more Medicare patients as more adults become eligible. Higher Medicare patient volumes are unlikely to offset the reimbursement cuts.

Diagnostic imaging centers will continue to operate in a fragmented landscape. Yet, Medicare cuts and rising healthcare costs will pressure consolidation activity. Companies will continue to enter the space due to rising demand for imaging services. Still, many small and locally focused imaging companies may be acquired by larger diagnostic imaging networks or join a health system. Cost pressures encourage small imaging centers to join a larger group or health system. Larger imaging centers can better adopt new and expensive technology and keep pace with rising wages.

industry_definition: This industry includes outpatient freestanding facilities that use machines and techniques to create images of the inside of a patient's body. The technology depends on symptoms and the part of the body being examined. Operators use various types of diagnostic imaging, including X-rays, CT scans, nuclear medicine scans, MRI scans and ultrasounds. Imaging facilities within a larger hospital are excluded, but mobile laboratories are included.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: An aging population's medical needs drive patient volumes.
Cost pressures strain imaging centers' operating environment.
An aging population translates into higher healthcare consumption.
Diagnostic imaging centers navigate a complex regulatory environment.
Private insurers are the largest payers of diagnostic imaging.
Imaging services necessary to nonelective care are more resistant to fluctuations, since diagnostic imaging has no substitutes.
Population hubs support diagnostic imaging centers.
Demographic trends can influence the location of imaging centers.
Diagnostic imaging centers rely on reputation for referrals.
Advances in imaging equipment translate to better patient outcomes.
While tech investment reduces imaging centers' reliance on employees, wages remain the largest expense for the industry.
A mix of cost pressures limits profit growth. Reimbursement cuts, inflation and staffing shortages strain profitability for diagnostic imaging centers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Reimbursements from private payors include payments received from commercial health plans. Private insurance providers will be the largest payers of diagnostic imaging in 2023.

Private revenue sources include reimbursements from Medicaid and Medicare and grants or loans from federal or state agencies. Imaging centers are receiving a growing share of payments from Medicare and Medicaid. As the population ages, more individuals become eligible for Medicare, increasing payments from the insurance program. An aging population's expanding medical needs include diagnostic services. The prevalence of disease increases with age, which requires diagnostic imaging to diagnose correctly.

Other sources of diagnostic imaging revenue include payments for non-patient care, workers' compensation and veterans' and active service health benefits. Centers that perform more types of imaging services will receive more payments from different sources. Some imaging centers generate additional revenue by renting out their machines. Diversifying income streams helps imaging providers mitigate volatility.

Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients for any care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance. Out-of-pocket payments also includes payments from self-pay patients. Payments from self-pay patients fluctuate with economic conditions. Uninsured patients are likely to avoid medical treatment unless necessary when worried about their current or future ability to pay for imaging.

products_and_services.product_description: Computed Tomography (CT) scans use specialized equipment to show detailed images of internal organs.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans take detailed pictures of the inside of the body using a large magnet and radio waves.

Ultrasound imaging is a non-invasive diagnostic medical test that produces internal images of the body. Ultrasounds are also commonly used in prenatal care to monitor the growth and development of a fetus.
Diagnostic imaging centers perform nonpatient care and rent, resell or lease of imaging equipment.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Device Manufacturing in the US
Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Primary Care Doctors in the US
Emergency & Other Outpatient Care Centers in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: A GROWING SENIOR POPULATION BOOSTS DEMAND FOR CT SCANS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Computerized tomography (CT) scans use specialized equipment to show detailed images of internal organs. Healthcare providers order CT scans to discover brain injuries or tumors. They can also be used to examine internal organs or bodily abnormalities. CT scans are resistant to changes in insurance coverage or economic fluctuations, as these scans are vital in nonelective or emergency care. CT scan usage has increased in recent years, an outcome of rising healthcare expenditures and the expanding medical needs of an aging population.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: IMPROVEMENTS IN MRI TECHNOLOGY TRANSLATE INTO HIGHER UTILIZATION
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans take detailed pictures of the inside of the body using a large magnet and radio waves. MRI scans produce high-contrast resolution images that display potential issues in the organs and soft tissues. An aging population will expand the use of MRIs moving forward. The use of MRIs will likely increase as they become easier to use and less expensive to maintain.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: ADOPTION OF POINT-OF-CARE ULTRASOUNDS THREATENS TRADITIONAL ULTRASOUND IMAGING
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Ultrasound imaging is a non-invasive diagnostic medical test that produces internal images of the body. Ultrasounds are also commonly used in prenatal care to monitor the growth and development of a fetus. This segment has slightly fallen as a percentage of revenue in recent years. The popularity of point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) surged during the COVID-19 pandemic. POCUS allows healthcare providers to provide an ultrasound to patients wherever they are being treated, potentially limiting referrals to imaging centers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: HIGH COST OF IMAGING EQUIPMENT ENCOURAGES RENTALS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Diagnostic imaging centers perform nonpatient care and rent, resell or lease of imaging equipment. Healthcare providers can outsource images to radiologists at an imaging center for a diagnosis. Imaging equipment is expensive, making the cost too substantial for some healthcare providers. Healthcare providers will lease imaging equipment from diagnostic centers for cost-savings.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As a central population hub, this area comprises the most diagnostic imaging centers to address the needs of its population.

Florida's population has the highest proportion of adults aged 65 and older. Adults 65 and older consume more healthcare services than any other demographic, attracting a variety of healthcare providers to the area. Healthcare providers refer patients to nearby imaging centers, incentivizing centers to operate in Florida.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of imaging centers mirrors its share of the population. Pennsylvania and New York contribute substantially to the share of providers in this region. Densely populated cities in New York influence the number of imaging centers in the state. New York City has more residents than North Dakota, Wyoming and Alabama combined, warranting a greater need for more imaging centers. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, New York has the most of radiologists in the US, an outcome of the state's extensive healthcare systems.
The West's share of imaging centers falls closely in line with its share of the US population.
California has the highest number of clinics in this region and the entire US because of its population density and concentration of referring healthcare facilities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Diagnostic imaging centers must receive a Certificate of Need before any construction, renovation or major medical equipment acquisitions.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Imaging centers must follow criteria of HIPAA for storing, sharing or sending private patient data.
The Joint Commission evaluates imaging centers for compliance with patient safety and quality standards required for reimbursement.
The FDA regulates all medical devices used in diagnostic imaging for safety and effectiveness.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
regulations_points.regulation_description: CMS implemented the Quality Payment Program, linking reimbursement to imaging centers' performance on quality measures.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Rising investment into innovative imaging equipment doesn't offset the industry's substantial labor requirements.

basis_points.basis_description: Diagnostic imaging centers rely on reputation for referrals. Without referrals, imaging centers wouldn't see patient volume.
Advances in imaging equipment translate to better patient outcomes. Imaging centers adopting top-of-the-line equipment are most competitive.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Diagnostic imaging has historically been a fragmented industry. Small, independent imaging centers operate as standalone facilities that provide treatment to local patients.
Diagnostic imaging centers aren't the first stop in healthcare delivery. Imaging centers receive referrals from local hospitals or physicians.
Cost pressures incentivize imaging centers to consolidate with larger groups or health systems.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Expanding wage expenses may slightly offset the higher capital requirements, keeping depreciation low.
Rising investment in software can also temper depreciation.
Chronic staffing shortages drive wage growth, while inflationary pressures have led to higher costs for imaging equipment, medical consumables and repairs.
Year-over-year Medicare reimbursement cuts also reduce the total revenue imaging centers receive per imaging service.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Rising investment into innovative imaging equipment
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Rising investment into innovative imaging equipment doesn't offset the industry's substantial labor requirements.
The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Imaging Centers Have a Vital Role in Healthcare
volatility_points.volatility_description: Healthcare providers can outsource images to radiologists at an imaging center for a diagnosis.
Substitutes for imaging centers are limited, so patients and healthcare providers don't have lower-cost options to choose from.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Growing senior population boosts demand for CT scans
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: A growing senior population boosts demand for CT scans, which are resistant to changes in insurance coverage or economic fluctuations.
Improvements in MRI Technology Translate into Higher Utilization as they become easier to use and less expensive to maintain.
Adoption of Point-of-Care Ultrasounds Threatens Traditional Ultrasound Imaging as they allow healthcare providers to provide ultrasounds wherever patients are treated.

FAQs.question: Does the company have a system in place to either leverage or minimize the potential adverse effects of changes in individuals' access to health insurance?
How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: Diagnostic imaging centers partner with healthcare providers to be the primary provider of testing services.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Imaging centers are usually based near healthcare providers.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage visits from individuals who lack health insurance?
FAQs.answer: Diagnostic imaging services typically do not carry a price that the average patient cannot afford to pay out-of-pocket.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Diagnostic imaging centers are always looking for ways to make testing more efficient and less labor-intensive.

FAQs.question: Does the company have a system to either leverage or minimize the potential adverse effects of changes in reimbursement rates?
FAQs.answer: Reimbursement rates for imaging centers have been impacted by healthcare reform.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Centers must be cautious when handling samples to avoid giving false test results.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Some diagnostic imaging centers have sought consolidation to keep costs low.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company have to replace its equipment?
FAQs.answer: Diagnostic imaging centers must update their equipment often to ensure they provide the best quality service.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize advanced technology and techniques to its advantage? How advanced are the technical capabilities of your company?
FAQs.answer: Operators should have sound billing systems and efficient diagnostic equipment. They need to keep abreast of advances in the field to maintain a competitive edge.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you by a satisfied client?
FAQs.answer: It is essential to establish a strong reputation and relationship with referring doctors, hospitals and managed-care entities.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Successful industry operators should have collection points and centers near hospitals, referring doctors and the public.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue comes from Medicare and Medicaid? How does a rise in federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid benefit your company?
FAQs.answer: Federal Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements account for a significant portion of industry revenue and can reduce the cost of services to certain patients, stimulating greater demand from these patients.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue comes from patients with private health insurance? How do you plan to mitigate the threat of a decrease in the number of people with private health insurance?
FAQs.answer: Health insurance can reduce patients' out-of-pocket costs for healthcare, thereby encouraging individuals to visit their physicians. Moreover, payments from private insurance make up a significant source of industry revenue. Healthcare insurers have taken steps to control pricing, which dampens demand for healthcare services.

FAQs.question: How does your company benefit from or guard against changes in the economy's health expenditure?
FAQs.answer: As spending on health in the United States increases, it will positively impact expenditure on industry services.
